The competition for voiceover work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording of what she can do – is very important. “It’s worth making a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she is successful because of her hard work and talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel or practicing your voices, it’s about setting goals and not giving up.”
For anyone who wants to do voiceovers, Shirley suggests going to special workshops. She thinks it is important to love voices. She describes herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been doing an American voice, it can stay with me for hours or even days,” she says. “My children are used to me talking in different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is normal because many kids dream of being cartoonists, like they dream of being race car drivers. But most people stop dreaming and choose more practical jobs, like being a lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, but some people do it.
Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to be one for a long time. I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, drew for school papers, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college. After I graduated, I showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted political cartoons about local issues. I drew some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money to live on.
You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree or a lot of money, and you don’t even have to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it was that easy, there would be many more cartoonists. The skills needed to be a cartoonist are not hard to learn, but it is still a tough job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you really want to do it. It is easier to get a regular job that pays well and gives you time for family and hobbies.
The more skills you have, the better chance you have to make a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also written, drawn caricatures, and done some design work. I take any job because you can learn a lot, even from work you don’t want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about the world.
What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But now, most cartoonists have to sell their own work. The better you are at selling, the more successful you will be. I have seen cartoonists who are not very creative but are good at business do much better than those who are very talented but don’t know how to sell their work.
Many people worry about someone stealing their ideas, but they have never sold a cartoon. Some are so scared that they won’t even let others see their work! To protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will care about your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar from Japan. I usually don’t like to throw things away, so I felt bad about this. I took it to the dump and was going to put it in the rubbish when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I said yes, and he asked if he could have it. I said yes, and we went our separate ways. After that, I felt sad about giving it away.
A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. That’s how I felt when I read an email from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes and sells guitars. He said, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name on a label on the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy! I would have given him anything, but his price was fair.
I remembered how my dad liked to put name labels on my things, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. But I didn’t get better at it, so I switched to the electric guitar, which was easier to play. At that time, punk music was also popular, and anyone could be a rock star.
When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap on my shoulder because electric guitars are played while standing. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands knew what to do. My fingers felt a little pain from pressing the strings to play.
The electric guitar is not usually played alone. Now that I am learning it again, I think I should start a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers”!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. I wrote a book called *Insomniac* about people who cannot sleep well. I wanted to warn people about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Sleep is very important for our minds, bodies, and feelings. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is. It is good that people are talking more about sleep now. 
But what about dreams? I have not heard much about dreams in this discussion. We often forget our dreams. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss the last hour or two of sleep. This lost sleep is mostly REM sleep, which is when we have the most dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. If a person lives for 90 years, they will spend about six or seven years in REM sleep.
When researchers take away REM sleep from people, they find that the next night, people have more REM sleep. This shows that dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM sleep. Many people agreed with the psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams helps us understand our minds. But later studies showed that this was not so simple. Now, researchers focus more on the physical reasons for dreams rather than the psychological ones. 
Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University, says that researchers do not agree on many things about dreams. Dreams are important. At a meeting of sleep experts, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. This study found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. Pagel thinks that creative people use their dreams more. 
It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wonder if only creative people need their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways. Dreams can help us find new patterns and think differently. 
For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to think of a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They think of unexpected ideas. This is what creativity is. I write better when I wake up from strong dreams. Even a bad dream can help me think better. On those days, my ideas come out quickly. 
Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We all live in a complex world. We need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important. 
**Questions:**
1. What is the name of the book the author wrote?
2. Why is sleep important for us?
3. What happens when people wake up early and miss REM sleep?
4. Who remembers and uses their dreams better, according to Pagel?
5. Why do we need to dream?

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small town by the sea in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see many empty frames on the walls and pictures of her two daughters. Susie is a talented artist who copies famous paintings. She can make copies of paintings from the early 20th century and the 16th century very well. 
"I don’t keep my own paintings," Susie says. "As soon as I finish them, I sell them." Susie is very busy. In her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted many famous artists' works, like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that experts sometimes think they are the real paintings. While the real paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how long she works on them. 
Susie does not tell the names of her clients, but they include art galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off. One famous buyer likes to say he has a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. Susie says, "Many famous people pretend my copies are the originals. That is their choice." Some collectors keep the real painting in a safe place and show Susie’s copy instead.
Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old painting, she tries to make it look as real as possible. She believes that doing a bad job would not be fair to the original artist. She puts her signature on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real painting, and even though some people make money this way, Susie has never wanted to do that. People who make fake art often get into trouble. 
Susie is not rich, and she has had hard times, but now her life is better. She does not want to risk her good name with collectors and artists. Susie did not always copy paintings. After she finished her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She earned very little money, but it helped her learn important skills. She had to be very careful and get things right the first time. She is happy she found a job that pays better.
When young artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and to be accurate. She has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants and make copies of old paintings, but she now focuses on French impressionist artists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 
Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie believes that impressionist artists worked hard and paid attention to detail. This makes their art difficult to copy. People wonder why Susie does not create her own art. She explains that her work comes from many years of practice, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried to make her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. 
Susie is a perfectionist, and she wants everything to be just right.

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything else when she was a racer. She wanted to be the fastest person on the water. Since she was a child, the sea was her big passion. She felt a strong connection with her boats. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, life felt boring. People wanted to know about her races, but she just wanted to be back on the ocean, testing herself against nature.
After she came second in a big race called the Vendée Globe, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She took me into the tiny cabin where she lived for 94 days. She talked about how she planned everything carefully, even how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. She said preparation was very important. She showed me her food, a small gas stove, and medical supplies. She took care of her boat because her life depended on it.
Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small and beautiful, but also fragile. She had a big change in her life when she went to South Georgia, a lonely island in the south Atlantic. There, she helped with a study of albatross birds. This made her think differently about the world. She saw many old whaling stations and felt it was a warning. She thought we take what we want and then leave.
When I visited Ellen’s office, she was finishing a call. She told me we need to act now to save the planet. She said we are running out of coal, oil, and gas. We need to find ways to not use everything up. At first, she said we should use less, but then she found a better way to think about it. Now, she talks about re-using things, like special carpet tiles.
For three years, she has been visiting factories and talking to people about our use of resources. She said, “I will never be an expert, but I love learning.” She felt she could not ignore the problems we face. Sailing felt selfish compared to this work. She started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a better future.
Ellen misses the adventure of being at sea. She said, “It is part of who I am. You feel connected to everything. You focus on survival.” She knows her new message is not as simple as being the fastest sailor. She may have been fast, but this work is the most important thing she has ever done.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old. He wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. Jordan hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and climb their own mountains. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Few people do this before they are thirty years old. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he turns 14.
Some famous climbers think it is not a good idea to take a 13-year-old up Mount Everest. They believe that while Jordan may be strong, he might not be emotionally ready. They also think he may not have enough experience to climb safely. Paul, Jordan's father, knows about these concerns. He says, "I know people criticize us, but we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence."
Paul also wants to make sure Jordan really wants to do this. He says, "This project is not about me becoming famous. At first, Jordan wanted to do this later, but we thought, 'Why not now?' We talk to him often to see if he still wants to climb." When asked why he wants to climb, Jordan says, "I just focus on my goal."
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest climber. Now, every adventure is shared online, and people want to break records. This makes it hard for Jordan. Some people think that trying to achieve records takes away the fun. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his journey online. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest.
Paul says, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym." 
**Questions:**
1. How old is Jordan Romero?
2. What mountain does Jordan want to climb?
3. Who are the members of "Team Romero"?
4. What is the goal of climbing Everest and Vinson Massif?
5. What do some famous climbers think about Jordan climbing Everest?
6. What does Paul say about criticism?
7. Why does Jordan want to climb?
8. How do people share their adventures today?

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they look confused. I just started studying music, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have any of their recordings. This is sad for people who love classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music, and most classical recordings sell only 300 copies. I find this hard to believe.
Why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for a long time? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that is the reason. The truth is that classical music does not attract many people, especially teenagers, who buy most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I don’t really like classical music. I enjoy many types of music, but I listen to classical music very little.
So, why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, classical music has many changes in mood, and we like fast music. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs more time and focus. Also, pop music talks about things that matter to teenagers, while classical music often does not.
The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely hear classical music in our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I don’t think many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. 
Some people think schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy playing classical music, but it is not their favorite music to listen to. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music. 
**Questions:**
1. What type of music do most teenagers listen to?
2. How many concert tickets sold last year were for classical music?
3. Why do teenagers find classical music hard to enjoy?
4. What do teenagers prefer to listen to when they want to relax?
5. Do many teenagers go to classical music concerts?

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side of the car, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hill; it looked confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gym, riding centre… “Riding centre,” said Bonnie, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” said her mother. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of behind me,” said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do it. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she said to herself. “I’ll be sent away soon anyway,” she thought, “so why not go now?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a big place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She walked carefully to the horses, treating them with respect. The horses were well cared for, and she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best!” she said. He was brown with a little white. He looked lively, and Bonnie liked that. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride the horse. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle,” she thought. The room with the riding gear was unlocked. Excited, she put a saddle on Maverick’s back and forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her old school friends called her Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said happily. “I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and a little breeze made her cheek feel warm. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

I met Cody Simpson before, and I was impressed by his quiet confidence. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia. He has already released many successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of many fans? 
Cody says, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven." He remembers that he was swimming and surfing every day. These activities were very important to him. When he was 13, he was in high school and posted some videos online. 
These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans wanted to see more videos on social media. Cody recorded more videos at home, and the responses were amazing. 
Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches. But then, record labels contacted him, and he had to make a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming or take a risk by moving to the US with his family. Cody decided to take the chance. 
He said, "It was very difficult for me to choose a career at such a young age. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. Most people were surprised because he is a quiet kid. 
Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to another part of the world. He gave up one dream to try to make another dream come true. His family stays out of the spotlight but supports him. Cody believes it is important to have good people around you to stay grounded. 
Sometimes, he thinks about how his decision affects his little brother and sister. His brother is eight years old and travels the world with him. Cody worries about how this affects his brother, but his family always supports him. 
Cody says that success comes from being ready to say "yes" to big opportunities, even if it is scary. He adds, "Everything happened so fast and unexpectedly. Now, I go to countries I never thought I would visit and play in front of many fans. It is something many people dream of, but I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I squinted and looked upstream at the sandbags. They were there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from moving the sandbags. Last week, I worked with many adults in the town for long hours to help. My grandfather did not notice much. 
I looked at the dark water from the factory in Milltown. There was thin ice on both sides of the water. I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit. I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I did not know him. He was trying to balance on the ice near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and put on my kayaking jacket. I checked my pocket for my lucky chain. It is a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Only my grandfather, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. 
I touched the chain and went to the kitchen. “Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You are up early for a Saturday. I will make brunch after your training. Be careful.” “Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. “Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” “Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was clear because I was wearing my wetsuit. Grandpa always gets angry, but I try to ignore it. “What is the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went to the bathroom and slammed the door. My mom came to me with a kind smile. “Don’t worry about him. He’s…” “...not himself right now,” I said. I wanted to say he always acts this way, but I kept quiet. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me pictures of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old pictures still hang on his wall, with his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, I want to stay close to him, even if he is grumpy. 
My mom smiled. “At least he is coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your hard work, even on these cold days!” I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It will be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my trip.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. I stepped into the backyard and hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, there was a painting that was not in a frame. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s paintings, but it looked different and was not finished. 
“Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” Jess looked at the painting. There was a river in it, but it was not a river she knew. It looked like a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a spooky way. The riverbank was very small, with a little green that was hard to see. The eye was drawn to the pale water and a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. Jess thought about autumn coming after a long summer.
Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others think about them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. “River Boy.” The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why. 
Then Jess looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 
“Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 
“Mum! You should have known better.” 
“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said.” 
Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would say. “He told you it’s not up to the artist to explain a painting because each painting has its own life and language, just like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. And he said painting is hard work without having to explain it to everyone.” 
Mum laughed. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 
“Inspire?” 
“Someone who helps an artist.” Jess knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually said the muse was not helping him or that he had to be nice to the muse. He never said the muse was about her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a real person. It was hard to think that anyone could inspire someone as stubborn as Grandpa. 
“He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He has been painting all his life.”

This morning, I woke up and did not mean to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. It might have been an accident. Maybe I tripped over the bed with Dad’s knife in my hand, and the knife could have gone into the carpet. I did not want to damage the carpet. I did not wake up and think, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at that moment. Afterward, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. 
What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. My Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is very cute! It is small, painted white, and has pink and blue flowers on it. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there. I keep my shells and stones in it. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was very happy when she gave it to me! 
The cabinet is a corner cabinet, so it has to stand in a corner. My bedroom is the smallest room in the house. It is shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad, my sister Angela has the back room, and my brother Tom has the little room over the garage. I have the smallest room, which is like a broom cupboard. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have Tom’s room. But Angela is only fifteen, so I think I will be in my small room for a long time. 
I do not mind; I like my little bedroom. It is cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is, there are not many corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet in the space between the roof and the floor, but it was a little too tall. I thought, if I cannot cut the cabinet, maybe I can cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like a good idea. Dad always tells us to “think outside the box.” That is what I was trying to do!

The book ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of tiny people. They live in the walls and floors of a house and take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to make a TV show from the book, I knew it would be hard to make everyone happy. People who love the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book because I did not want people to say I did it wrong. The author wanted the show to show the Borrowers' view, not the humans' view, which made filming harder.
The most important thing was to show the right size. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans. So, when we filmed the Borrowers walking or going on their missions, we had to be ten times further away than usual. When we filmed the human world, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from very low, about 15 centimeters high. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for special shots. 
One big problem was making the shadows look right when we combined the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We made a special way to do this. After the show, the famous director George Lucas called me to ask how I did it. The only set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with big objects to make the actors look small. It was very strange. I remember the coins we used; they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because the crew laughed so much.
In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers go down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was very scary. I wanted to get the costumes right, which was hard for other directors. I had the costumes made from heavy material so they looked like doll clothes. This made it hard for the main actress to move. She could not sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they liked the costumes!
Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to act with things that were not really there. I drew pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I drew 2,000 pictures! They were not perfect, but they worked. We did not have enough money for special effects during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly. One time, I filmed a whole scene and then realized there was no film in the camera! But in the end, everything came together, and I think the show was successful in showing the magic of the books.
**Questions:**
1. What is the main idea of the book ‘The Borrowers’?
2. Why was it hard for the director to make the TV show?
3. How much smaller are the Borrowers than humans?
4. What did the crew have to do to film the Borrowers' perspective?
5. What material was used for the costumes?
6. How many pictures did the director draw for the scenes?
7. What happened when the actors filmed the scene going down the drain?

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, thinking there might be journalists, but there aren’t any. I know that soon there will be people acting crazy. It always happens. The fake smiles, the new friends who want something from me. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone at this new school. But I wanted this. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet normal kids. Kids with parents who have regular jobs, like working in an office or cutting grass. That would be so cool.
I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking serious. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I say again. The secretary looks confused. “Oh,” she says and types my last name. That’s good because not many people know my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she says. Then she gives me my schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great! I like English. But I will be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look lost. 
When I get to the door, I hear the teacher calling names. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the back of the class. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my fancy shoes with flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher stops calling names. “Desert... McGraw?” she says. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After that, she lets us talk to each other! 
“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few answers. I could say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters. Or I could say what my dad thinks: “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album.” He thinks it has energy and culture. I think he just wants to relax at the beach. “My dad had to move here,” I tell her. “What does he do?” she asks. I know everyone will find out soon, but I want to pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” She seems not to care much. That’s good.

Today, many American teenage girls are expected to do a lot. They should be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. Being a teenager in America is not easy. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average. They need to work hard and show ambition. 
Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, “People forget how much pressure we have. We have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and we also want to have a social life.” Even with all this stress, people still think teenagers are lazy, loud, and selfish. Kristen believes this is not fair. 
She says many people think teenagers only watch TV or use their phones all the time. While she does have her phone close to her, she uses it for important things, not just for fun. Teenagers use their phones to help with schoolwork and stay connected. Now, students can do homework anywhere, not just at school. 
Many teenagers wake up early, around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m., and go to bed late, often after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They do not get enough sleep. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get enough sleep, which is nine hours a night. 
Lindamarie Olsen, another teenager, says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, this is not much. She does not spend her free time on social media or TV. Instead, she likes to volunteer. She says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves, but I love helping others.” 
In the future, teenagers will still be working hard and changing the world, just like they do today. 
---
**Questions:**
1. What are some things American teenage girls are expected to do?
2. How does Kristen feel about the pressure on teenagers?
3. What does Kristen use her phone for?
4. How many hours of sleep do most teenagers get?
5. What does Lindamarie like to do in her free time?

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a small mountain town in the US. This town is surrounded by wild nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers join.
One weekend in late spring, I joined them. They were going to release a high-altitude balloon to try to see shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and makes a bright light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer to check the temperature as the balloon went up. They also put two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to find it later. They used a gas tank, given by a friend from another state, to fill the balloon with gas. The balloon grew to the size of a small car. An older boy drove for seven hours to get the gas tank. He said, “I didn’t really mind.” For kids in this club, this is normal.
Finally, it was time for the balloon to go up. They counted down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon started to rise. Some of the kids ran and used flashlights to follow the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky. It was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a big city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. One girl said quietly, “We’re the only ones talking.” Another girl whispered, “I know.” Suddenly, a meteor flew across the sky.
As the balloon rose, the air pressure changed, and the balloon got bigger until it popped with a loud noise. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. The group’s leader said, “Recoveries are a big part of the program.” They have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. He added, “This journey helps us know the land better.”
This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the mountain. They had to decide if they should drive or walk. It could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high mountain or in a tall tree. The leader said, “These students know the Eastern Sierra well. What seems wild to some is normal for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not catch any shooting stars. This was a little disappointing, but it gave them a chance to talk about science and how things work in the atmosphere. It was also another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan says that she did not like science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen years old. It happened by chance. Her younger brother was very interested in dinosaurs, which she did not care about at first. One day, she helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. This surprised her, and she decided she wanted to study it.
Chloe remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius. He was young and already famous. At first, she was very nervous because she thought he might think she was just a silly kid asking too many questions. But he was friendly and listened to her, which made her feel better.
Chloe thinks that movies and TV shows often show palaeontologists in a wrong way. She says that films like Jurassic Park make people interested in dinosaurs, but they do not show what palaeontologists really do. She feels that they are often shown as strange geniuses or awkward people who cannot talk to others. 
In her job, Chloe does many things. She digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs to study fossils, and writes for science publications. Sometimes, she talks to the public about science, especially to young people. She believes it is important to help them understand science better. Talking about dinosaurs can make children excited about nature and science.
Chloe worked on a TV documentary called Walking with Dinosaurs. She helped make sure the dinosaurs were shown correctly. She did not have to change much because the show was accurate. The dinosaurs in this program are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They look more real.
Chloe thinks dinosaurs are still interesting to people because they make us curious. They remind us that there is still much to discover in the world. Palaeontology is like traveling back in time.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know you are not “there yet.” You keep asking, “Are we there yet?” But when you arrive, it is not “there” anymore; it is “here.” If you think you are “there,” you should ask, “Are we here yet?” 
Parents hear this question many times on long car trips. Kids might think it is hard, but it is nice to sit in the back seat. You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while looking at the beautiful views outside. 
In the front seat, there is a parent who gives juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio, and keeps everything running smoothly. 
But sometimes, things can get crazy. For example, my younger brother, Tim, might put his foot on my side of the seat. I do not like that, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, we are fighting, and our parents have to separate us while driving. They tell Tim to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. 
After a while, I try to read, but I feel something on my arm. The window is closed, so I wonder where it is coming from. Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks it is okay. This makes me angry. 
Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he sometimes says, “Yes, we are here. Get out of the car.” But we are still driving fast on the highway. Then he says, “Maybe we are not there yet.” This makes us quiet for a while. 
You know you are finally “there” when the adults get out of the car and go far away from the kids. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is: no, you are not there yet.
---
**Questions:**
1. What do kids often ask during a long car trip?
2. What can kids do in the back seat of the car?
3. What does Tim do that makes the narrator angry?
4. How does Dad answer the question “Are we there yet?” sometimes?
5. How do you know when you have arrived at your destination?

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK. In their café, people can enjoy coffee and cake, and also play board games. John and Zuzi want people to have fun and come back again. Zuzi says they started this business because there is a lot of technology today. Many people are busy with their phones and gadgets. They wanted to help people spend time together and talk to each other.
The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games have simple themes, like farming and building. The first Eurogame was called The Settlers of Catan, made by a German designer named Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other. Everyone stays involved and has fun until the end of the game.
There are also ‘co-operative’ games where all players work together to win or lose as a team. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, created by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Matt was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling scared but also happy at the end, no matter who won.
Matt loved board games as a child, but sometimes he felt disappointed when the games were not fun. With help from his uncle, he tried to make better games. Pandemic became very popular and had a lot of storytelling. It is like a video game because players develop characters and the story changes as they play.
The video game industry has helped board games become more popular. Many people now play games on their phones. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone plays games on their smartphones. More people are open to playing games than ever before.
At first, video games allowed people to play together in the same room. But then, many video games moved online, and players were not together anymore. Some people who liked video games wanted to play games with others in person again. In John and Zuzi's busy café, board games have become more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something to share with others in real life, and this trend will continue. 
**Questions:**
1. Where is John and Zuzi's café located?
2. What do people enjoy at the café besides coffee and cake?
3. What is a Eurogame?
4. Who created the game The Settlers of Catan?
5. What is the main idea of the game Pandemic?
6. Why did Matt Leacock want to create better games?
7. How has the video game industry helped board games?

Jamie Scott is a musician from the UK. He has written and produced many popular songs. His story shows that hard work and not giving up are very important in music, even if you start slowly. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him learn to play the guitar. He only listened to a local radio station at home, which played music for older people. Because of this, he did not hear modern songs until he was 12 years old.
When he was young, Jamie had to choose between playing tennis and making music. He played tennis at a high level, but he liked music more. He spent his lunch breaks in the music room at school, learning songs on the piano. At 17, he left school to become a performer. He worked with a friend who played guitar but did not want to be a performer. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to make music. His dad said he had 18 months to succeed, or he would need to find a job.
At 19, Jamie got a deal with a music publisher after writing one song. However, the record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to stop working with his friend. He found success as a songwriter instead of a performer. After some hard times with a record label in the UK, he changed to another label to release a new album, but he did not become famous right away.
Jamie believes he has been in the wrong place at the wrong time as a performer, but he has been successful as a writer. He helps new artists and wants to write songs that many people will love. He tells artists that it is okay to want their music to be popular. He wants to write great songs that can be number one hits. Jamie is honest about his goals and works hard to create the best music. He wants to write songs that will be loved for a long time.

Tony Connor is a new type of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, do not know him because we do not watch videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is a "street trials cyclist." This means he jumps from hard places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other strange places. People film these jumps and put them online.
I met Tony in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys know him well, and some older people come to say he is "an absolute legend." After watching him, I agree. At first, I was not sure about him, but I was impressed by his courage and creativity. Before each jump, he explains what he wants to do, and sometimes I think he cannot do it. But when I tell him he did a great job, he seems not very happy.
Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans. He prefers to do things instead of just talking about them. This is funny because his fame comes from social media and cameras that help make videos. He says, "This technology helps people like me earn money." Sometimes he feels like everyone is filming themselves or looking at screens, and he does not like that.
Tony makes good money from his videos, which is different from people in the past who did similar things as a hobby. After many years of talking to top athletes, I think two things help a child become a great athlete: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are often more important than talent. In risky sports, it is very important to be strong mentally.
Even in the park, Tony fell a few times when trying new things. But he got up and kept trying until he could do it. Some people do not see him as a hero. They think he takes too many risks. He says, "People who say this may care, but they do not understand. They probably have never tried riding a trials bike and do not know the sport. They do not see that I get advice from experts to stay safe."
Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He says, "People are different. Some are not scared, and they should not do these sports. It is smart to know the dangers. Some people cannot get over their fear, but I can. I feel scared but find a way to keep going. I am not addicted to risk. I spend a lot of time planning and getting ready. Sometimes I ride around to feel ready before trying a new jump. I know I must stay calm before I jump. If I focus completely, I will be fine."
---
**Questions:**
1. What type of cyclist is Tony Connor?
2. Where did the interview with Tony take place?
3. How do local boys feel about Tony?
4. What does Tony think about being a celebrity?
5. What two qualities help a child become a great athlete, according to the writer?
6. How does Tony feel when he tries new jumps?
7. What does Tony say about people who think he takes too many risks?

'Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This wire was 66 metres above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net. She only had a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her keep her balance, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 
Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. She already had some circus skills, but she found out that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know I needed to be so strong. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill. Then I did an hour of exercises, and another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’
On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen took deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-metre walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said after. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ But this experience did not stop Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

'In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing. This is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada in a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved cars and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and used it to go to Amsterdam for a holiday. “That trip opened my eyes,” he says. “I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff did not want a normal bike. He wanted to build a special one. “The craziest bike I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to learn how they were made.” After two tries in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally started his trip in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. “I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but I never regretted my penny farthing. The further I went from home, the more people were amazed by it.” His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. He got very sick and stayed in a hostel bed without medicine for ten days. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. But now, Jeff says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”'

"I work at a university in the US. My team and I are learning about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’. This tool helps us see the ducks at night! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers are very low. We don’t know if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but we don’t know what they do at night. The night-vision scope will help us see clearly, even when there is no moon. This will help us learn more and take better care of their home.
Our work is hard. There are four of us, and we work six hours every day. We have studied ducks in different places. Sometimes, I have to take a boat to see the ducks and write down what I see. The weather can be difficult. Some nights are warm, but many nights are wet. It is very quiet, and I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. I like this challenge, especially when I think about summer. In summer, we will work in a laboratory and look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important. I wouldn’t change this job for anything!"

"When I tell people what my job is, they often don’t believe me. But I am not joking! I work with chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure customers get good chocolate from my company. Every week, I get small samples from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the nuts and fruit we use in the chocolate. I spend time choosing the best ones to use. 
Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the chocolate I make. I also share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients. It is great to have my own space during the day. 
No two days are the same in my job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety in my job, even more than the chocolate! 
People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I have worked with it for a long time, and I still love to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!"

'Have you ever thought about what it is like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills. Students learn to juggle, throw, and catch things like balls or even fire. They also learn trapeze, which is flying in the air above an audience. 
The course lasts one year. Students take more risks as they learn, and parents can come to some classes to see how they are doing. Sophia says, “To have a career in the circus, performers need to do different things. It is important to keep performances exciting. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great thing is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is very important too. Circus artists train every day to stay strong. Training is important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always want to improve their skills. 
Some people think circus performers get hurt a lot or only work for a short time each year. But the real challenge is thinking about the future. You can only travel and perform when you are young, and then you need to think about other jobs.” The course also teaches business planning. Many past students start their own businesses around the world and share their experiences. Sophia warns that this job is not for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not have a regular salary. It is also competitive, but it is a lot of fun!”'

'You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a backing singer. This means she sings in the background to help the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not good enough to be main singers. This is not true – they often have to be better. People like Mariam are very important in the music industry! 
Mariam says, “What I love about my job is that when I go to the recording studio, I never know what I will sing. It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it is a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask me to do. One time, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!”
Mariam explains that good musical skills are very important for her work, and she must learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. She remembers her first time recording background music for a film. It was very hard because there were eight of them, each singing a different part, and there was also an orchestra. She was scared because if she made a mistake, they would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long.
One of her favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to her sing their song, they can learn how to make it better.'

'Julie Deane started with little knowledge about fashion, but she created a successful business with her satchels. A satchel is a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. Now, these bags are sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before she chose to make satchels, Julie thought about different businesses, like cake decorating and party planning. She wanted to make the right choice. Some people told her there was no need for satchels, but Julie believed in her idea. 
Julie worked with her family, especially her mother, who had never worked before but was good at business. The design of the satchels came from children’s storybooks. Julie did not know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her succeed. At first, she sold only one satchel a week. To get more attention, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them. They did, and more people became interested. Now, her company makes satchels faster.
Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity uses her satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she asks the online community for ideas to create new styles. There was a difficult time when another company copied her design, so now she makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors say her office has a positive feeling, and people enjoy working there. There is a new factory, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it special.'

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky liked to do many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could be a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to train and do her schoolwork.
When they were teenagers, Jamie loved cycling. He bought a special racing bike and started to compete. Vicky thought this was exciting and wanted to try it too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was near her school, so it was easy for her to go to training after school.
Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. When she was 28, she stopped competing. Vicky said, “I loved winning, but I got tired of it. When the excitement goes away, there is no point.” Luckily, she found a new job.
Vicky works for a charity called CycleZone. “We help young people who do not enjoy sports,” she says. “First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves.” CycleZone helps young people come together and be part of a group.
The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky says, “Some people think having a celebrity is not always good for a charity. They say celebrities do it for attention, and this can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.”

Ana Ronson is a singer and songwriter from Ireland. Her parents did not play music, but there was always music in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert.
A year later, Ana's brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song called "Falling Stars" in just three days. She enjoyed writing so much that she took a songwriting course with a professional. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew a lot about music. But Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called "Something to Say" about this feeling. She shared this song online, and many people loved it and left nice comments.
Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to ask Ana to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone to tell her what to sing. But Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. All the tickets sold out quickly, and it was a wonderful night.
Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times in life because she feels she has more to say then. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how sad it made him. Ana hopes her fans will like her songs, but she wants to write about her own important experiences.

"Last year, I went on a great trip. I traveled by boat on a guided tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write stories about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not share that interest. I had always wanted to visit this area because our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. I asked Harry many times if I could go with him, and he finally said yes!
A few days before we left, there were storms where we were going. But the weather was good for the time we would be there. I was busy at work and did not have much time to plan, but Harry said he would take care of everything, so I felt better.
When we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our things into small boats, and started our journey. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast now. On the first morning, we only saw dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the fog made it hard to see. I enjoyed watching the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.
We often stopped to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I did not know. I loved that I did not have to worry about time. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. The beds were hard, but it felt nice to live without stress.
When it was time to go home, I felt sad. I did not want to return to normal life. But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!"

"My dad was a basketball player in Germany. His father was also a player. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of my dad's games. You might think I would love basketball, but I didn’t. I liked to tell my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often read a book instead of watching the games.
When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed to get better before playing in a real game. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After a few weeks, I played against another school. My parents came to watch, which made me nervous, but it was OK in the end!
For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well. I even joined an adult team before I moved to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was great to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents. At home, I couldn’t spend much time with my friends because of training, so that was not a big change for me. I got used to my new life, and my English got better quickly!
I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I was taller than most players in the league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

"Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism in college. I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I decided to become a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city, and I was happy to see how much I enjoyed it. I saw my city in a new way every time! After I finished my studies, I wanted to be a tour guide full-time. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that I needed to know a lot more to get a license. All tour guides in Chicago must answer many questions about the city, like its buildings, history, and public transport rules. After some hard but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and became an independent tour guide.
Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts. You also need to be entertaining and tell good stories. It is important to handle changes, like if a place is closed when you arrive. Tourists want to enjoy their tour, not hear about problems. I want my visitors to be happy, or they might leave a bad review online. Good reviews are very important because they help me get more customers. I try to make my tours fun and easy. Because I love my job, I usually get good reviews, and many visitors recommend my tours to others in Chicago."

"My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. She is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to help at an elephant sanctuary. This is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have things in common with the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing this kind of work. In the end, we had nothing to worry about. 
One of our main jobs was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun, even if I got wetter than the elephants!
The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By the light of the moon, we led the elephants into the forest where they slept at night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we did not have much space. We chose to do this because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff talked and played games.
Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I think she might be a little upset with herself because she missed her friends too much. But when she thinks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I know I will!"

"My name is Gina D’Costa, and I have a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers to many different customers. Hotels and offices often buy flowers for their reception areas. Sometimes, we provide flowers for businesses to use in their advertising pictures. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of it.
My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still sleeping, and my friends think I am crazy, but I love my job. It is often cold and dark at that time, but I don’t let it bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. It can be hard to choose flowers because there are so many beautiful ones. My favorite color is pink, so I would choose pink flowers for myself. But I have to remember that other people may want different flowers. Not all flowers are available all year, so I sometimes cannot find what customers want.
I don’t like arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but I have to do it. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then, we make flower bunches and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to think again about what they want. Some people may think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the money someone wants to spend. I wouldn’t want any other job!"

"My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films. It also has many films for kids on weekends. The cinema is close to my home, but a year ago, I felt something was missing. I wanted to talk about films with other people after watching them. So, I started a film club with two friends! 
We decided not to rent a cinema. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made it a great place for the film! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film. This helps us keep our prices low. We just want to cover our costs, not make money.
Each time we show a film, it gets easier for us, especially now that we have our own equipment. We can see how many tickets we sell online, so we don’t worry about empty seats. There is still a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us they had a great time, it makes us happy. 
Our website helps us a lot, and we are in touch with other film clubs in the country. We have visited them to see how they do things, but we always like coming back to our own club! We also started a blog because many people look online for film information instead of reading local papers. We put up some posters in cafés, but the best way to get new people is when others tell their friends about us. The audience loves the fun activities we have with each film. Last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

"When I was a child, I loved taking photographs. When I turned 15, I wanted to make my hobby better. I decided to take one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea. After a few weeks, I put my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my photos to others. I was happy to see that people liked my photos. I enjoyed taking pictures of many different things. Then, someone suggested that I should focus on one topic for my photos. I agreed and started taking more photos of nature, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were black and white, which was different from what other young photographers were doing. They were taking color photos. Sometimes, I doubted my project and almost gave up. But in the end, I believed in myself and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a photography competition for young people. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget when the judges told me I won first prize. I was so happy because my project was very important to me. It was the first time I realized my photography was good, and I could be a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I am happy with my career choice."

"I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year. I wanted to try camping and sailing and learn new skills like public speaking. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn something new. There are levels from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called ‘leaders’ help us. When you finish each level, you get a certificate.
When I first joined, my leader said I should help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was not sure about this because I had joined that club when I was eight, and I found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. But I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate.
Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I made good friends with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to it.
Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I want to go to college after school to become a youth worker, someone who works with children. I never thought about my future job before joining the club. This has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have several NYC certificates now, and one of them is for camping!"

"I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a place in the mountains, about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try it. I was too young to ask him if I could snowboard, but he loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy. In the end, I did well. After that, I loved snowboarding and got better at it. I started competing when I was ten. Some people do many competitions and get bored, but I still love to compete and win. This helps me work harder. I like not having a strict plan. Sometimes this works out well, like when I was the first girl to get a perfect score of 100 in a local competition. I was not sure I could do the jumps for this score until I tried. This made me trust myself more. 
In the summer, I train and study because there is no snow. I train every day, but I don’t have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends. This helps me deal with not doing what I love. I think about my future. Snowboarding is very important to me, but I want to have another job too, just in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I am thinking about becoming a doctor if I have time to go to college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever."

"When I was fifteen, I wanted the same things as my friends. I did not think about the future. For example, I did not know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday. I wanted a new phone too. My parents said I could only have one if I paid for it myself. So, I decided to work part-time and save money. I am thankful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. 
I worked every Saturday in a café, but I did not enjoy it. My parents suggested I start my own small business. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I thought it would be hard, but it was easy. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked the idea. My mum showed me how to make pretty things at home with simple tools and materials. 
I sold my first jewellery to my friends and family. They said they liked it, but I was not sure if it was good enough for other people. I wanted to know, so I rented a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewellery to take home. Soon, people from all over the country called us to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just me and my mum at the market!
