In the elevator to their room after the party, her grandfather said, “You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” 
Lucy liked that. She liked being someone important, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young. Being a concert pianist didn’t make her special at school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play difficult music. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

“It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to go outside more,” said Dad. It is hard to argue with him, so I wanted to see what experts say about this. It is interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have real friends, feel they belong, and are learning important skills for the digital world.
Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says that social media is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers use social media differently than adults. They do not just check emails or buy things; they live in it. This is not good or bad – it depends on how you use it.
Jim Matthews, a social media expert, says that social media is like the youth clubs that parents went to when they were young. It helps teenagers share jokes and talk about their lives. It helps them find their identity away from their parents and deal with issues with their friends.
Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says that being a teenager is a time to ask, “Who am I?” Social media can help with this. You can share your favorite music or sports and see how others think differently. Research shows that teenagers who use social media a lot are not more self-centered than those who do not.
Professor Andrew Phillips studies how young people use social media. He believes it helps quiet people with special interests connect with others. If you are one of the few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a group online with similar interests, you can feel more connected and popular in a new way.
Pauline White, a digital education expert, says that teenagers can find new interests online and create their own content. She believes social media is a way for teenagers to be creative. They can make videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers connect, learn, and share their work. This can help them get jobs in the future.
Every business uses social media to sell products and reach customers. If you have many friends on social media, they can be potential customers for your product. If you connect all your networks, you can reach more people.
Teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they grow up and start working. Matthews agrees that many sites allow people to work together to create and share content. Working together is an important skill in today’s world and helps you get a job.

When people think of a family vacation, they might not think of a long trip across nine states in the US and one province in Canada. But my parents wanted to have a fun family trip this summer. My dad wanted to plan a trip for us to spend time together. He often said, “Not many people do this anymore,” while my twin brother and I looked at each other in surprise.
In mid-June, we packed our car with bags, food, and clothes for any weather. I was excited but also worried about not having my own space for two weeks. With little room left in the car, we started our “Family Great American Road Trip.” We left our big house for smaller places to stay for the next five thousand miles. I wondered what this trip would be like.
We drove west through Oklahoma. Even though we were close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right-of-way on the road!
The next day, we woke up early and continued our trip. We saw deserts and then mountains. Each day was different, but they all felt similar. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that town showed us what we would experience later.
As we drove up the mountains, we learned that some roads are better for special cars called Jeeps. We saw old and new things everywhere we went. We often had to wait in traffic because of construction. We laughed when we saw big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument.
We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park. There, we watched the sunset over areas where bears live. Sometimes, we had to stop for bears crossing the road, which was exciting and funny. 
As we continued our trip, I forgot about life at home. Even the old hotel we stayed in, which had no internet or cell phone service, could not stop our fun. The views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we started our journey back home. My parents were right; you don’t need to go far away to find something special. 
It was nice to be home together, and I was happy that I didn’t fight with my brother during our long trip. We took three thousand photos of our adventures, and I knew I would remember the unexpected and fun moments the most.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and living at the college. She had the best room with a kitchen and a study area. Amy was happy because she also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, even if she did not want them to.
Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only remembered a few happy times with Daisy and did not know her grandfather. Daisy wanted Rose to stay with her, even if Rose's parents were not happy about it. Rose did not know why her parents did not like her grandmother, but they had a fight in the past. Rose had not seen Daisy since she was ten years old. 
Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked to meet people. Rose thought she would get many dinner invitations and shopping trips. This made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady; she went to many social events. 
Before the move, Dahlia talked to Rose. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating and exercise. But Rose wanted to be independent. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She hoped Daisy would understand. 
Dahlia gave Rose a new mobile phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They all agreed to trust each other. Rose would act mature, and Daisy would not be too strict. If they had problems, they would talk about it.
Rose was not a wild child. She had good friends, and her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school. This was her fourth school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this would be her last school before finishing. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life. 
**Questions:**
1. How old is Rose Frost?
2. Why is Rose moving to her grandmother's house?
3. What did Amy get for her room at the college?
4. How did Rose feel about living with her grandmother?
5. What did Dahlia give Rose before the move?

Charlotte Grainger talks about how her primary school teacher thought she might write a book. She says, “I thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed hard. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like sports. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’” The book Charlotte started writing at that age is now going to be published. She told her old teacher about it, and her teacher was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40 years old. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to do something she was good at.
It is a winter afternoon in the office of Charlotte’s publishers. I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, and I was surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a big achievement. It is exciting and well-written. The public relations person is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn’t. Charlotte is confident and smart, but she is also calm and not too proud.
Charlotte knows she is young. I ask her about the important questions in her book. She says, “I wanted to ask big questions, not give answers. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughs and adds, “I think my age doesn’t limit my understanding of the world, but I don’t think I am very wise. I just wanted to talk about taking responsibility.”
Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are shown in books. She thinks there are three types of teenagers in stories: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She feels annoyed by these types. “What if you are just fine? There aren’t many stories about teenagers who are okay. Some writers make it seem like teenagers don’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-confidence.”
Charlotte loves reading books by famous fantasy writers, but they almost made her stop writing. “These books talk about deep things in life. I wondered if I had to write like that to make a good book.” However, she likes a book called How Not to Write a Novel. “It says if the reader can guess what will happen next, the story is not exciting anymore.”
Some people might think Charlotte’s parents, who are journalists, helped her get her book published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. Charlotte knows she is lucky because it is hard to get anyone to read a first novel. “Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you have to do it on your own. In the end, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte says.

"‘Remember, speed is good, not bad,’ said Gareth, our teacher, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew up into the air, but something looked wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said kindly, ‘speed can be tricky.’ 
I thought maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On past ski trips, I liked to practice turns in the snow. I was not like the teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid to try because I didn’t know how, and I didn’t want to look silly. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps with fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam cubes – not a real way to learn for the slopes. 
After practicing inside, students went outside to try for real. ‘You will get better!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this, new ski jumpers just went down the slopes and hoped for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land in the wrong place, you will get hurt.’ The ‘wrong place’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down again. If you land in the right place, you keep moving forward. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important.
At first, it was hard for me to ignore my fear and go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to slow down, so I landed on the flat area. I didn’t fall, but I felt tired. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. 
On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being inside, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises copied the moves we would do while ski-jumping, and others helped us know where our bodies were in the air. Gareth told us what to do. I needed to work on my ‘aerial awareness’ – I only noticed when I was about to jump and then I found myself in the foam cubes. 
We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes before I finally landed correctly. Gareth was happy for me, and I felt proud. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last jump of the day, I made myself go fast, jumped, and landed in the right place. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold on tight. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage goes slowly up. Then, there is a quick drop, and your stomach feels funny. You go fast forward, turn left, and then go upside down. You feel scared and scream. But you chose to go to the amusement park, just like many other people do every year.
Amusement parks are very popular and make a lot of money. To make the exciting rides that people want, there are many engineers and designers working hard behind the scenes. They create rides that are fun but also safe. Designing rollercoasters is not easy. It is important to make the ride exciting but also to keep people safe. 
Many of the ideas for rollercoasters were created by a designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. He made rides that were very thrilling, but they were not always safe. Now, designers have to follow rules and use special designs for the rides. 
I talked to some experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, who is a "thrill engineer," said that the skill is in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts explained that it is important to make people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. 
To create a great ride, the teams must think of a fun story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase. They also want to make the ride taller, twistier, and have steeper drops. However, Professor Walker said that experience and testing are very important. Jeff Hornick, a director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to love thrills when designing rollercoasters.
I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, would change rollercoasters. Walker said that while new technology can be exciting, the real experience of the rollercoaster will always be the most important part for many years.

At 25 years old, Miranda Ellington has done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both things with her busy schedule. She says, “Dancing again helps me remember what it is like to be in a studio and follow the orders of choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers sometimes forget how hard it is to rehearse all day.”
As a choreographer, Miranda teaches young students. She enjoys this work. She says, “A new dancer is often open to new ideas. Working with students can be easier than working with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they do not always know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they can accept criticism better. Sometimes they challenge what I say, but I like their honest feedback.”
When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. She says, “There may be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers do not respond well to the music, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I cannot just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could try different pieces to make rehearsals more fun. But now, I always work on big productions where the music is already decided.”
Miranda does not want to stay with one place. She says, “It is important to meet new people. But I must remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I have to change how I work each time I go somewhere new. This helps me not to get stuck in my ways.”
We talk about a recent documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, “Some documentaries look nice but are not true. This one shows real life in a dance company. There is a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections. I smiled because I understood her struggle. She knows she is not doing it right but cannot make her body do what is needed. It is hard to watch, but it is real. People do not see how much work and dedication ballet needs.”
I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She says, “It is when everything comes together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Perfection is hard to achieve, but aiming high is important. It helps to cover up some mistakes. I have worked on productions where the dance steps are good, but the costumes or props are distracting. That is disappointing.”
Miranda has done many types of work, so I ask if she is a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She replies, “People want to label you, but I do not understand why. There is a trend to focus on one area of expertise. I do not agree with that, but maybe one day I will be known for one thing. For now, I want to explore more.”

"A friend asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I said that TV shows many amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to see and do? This conversation gave me the idea for my fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was giving away his old sofa, and it became the star of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to the sofa and used old seatbelts to hold it on my shoulders. I put my bags on the sofa and slept on it every night, even one night on the beach. Some friends helped me pull the sofa and encouraged me to keep going. I have walked on foot many times, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I could stop at cafés to relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to tell them how I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England instead of talking about the latest TV show. You can see the film on my website."

"I was excited when I read about swimming trips in the sea around small Greek islands. I had never tried group trips before. My brother was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a ticket for one person because many families go to the islands. I told him I would not be alone for long; I would join ten other people to swim around the small islands. He still looked confused, but he smiled and helped me get on the boat.
Before we started, our group had sent emails to each other, but we did not have much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would be with us, and they showed us how to talk to it. We swam a short distance to split us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I saw faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this swim, and I was very happy when I did it by myself.
The next days were similar: jumping in, swimming at a comfortable speed, and stopping to look at the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I swam faster and enjoyed them more. I did not need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come back next year."

"Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it is a great job. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with amazing people, I have a lot of free time, and my job is never boring. This is good for a young person like me! 
When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers. Some of them let me help. 
Later, when I wanted to change my job from banking, I remembered this. At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people like me. They were also changing careers. I practiced what to say before the interview. I talked about my skills and my work experience, not just that I loved to travel. Because of this, I got the job!
I think this job is good for many people. There are many reasons to like it, but free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard. There is a saying: 'No one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family. Even if we do not see each other all the time, we are still close. 
When I am not working, I do not take work home. If I have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!"

"At the summer camp where I work, I enjoy seeing the children do things they thought they could not do. Most of the children can swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but after some encouragement, they try and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel very happy. 
At the start of the week, some children miss home. It is not the youngest children who feel this way; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and they can do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time.
Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call a lot to ask how their child is. This is not necessary. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other things, so we tell the parents to call back later. We also see some children who come dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why."

'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with all-British actors was not easy. The UK has rules about how many performances young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 
The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s great that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful Gibson guitar.’ He told me that the young actors are very busy. ‘We have normal school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends,’ he said. 
What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre has special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 
The young actors were already musicians, with some playing different instruments, but none had played in a band before. They found it easy to play together. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is worth seeing.'
